perturbation.original_text: The undersigned hereby agree to jointly prepare and file with the applicable regulatory authorities this Schedule 13G or Schedule 13D and any future amendments thereto reporting each of the undersigned's ownership of securities of the issuer named herein, and hereby affirm that such Schedule 13G or Schedule 13D is being filed on behalf of each of the undersigned pursuant to and in accordance with the provisions of Rule 13d-1(k) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
perturbation.changed_text: The undersigned hereby agree to jointly prepare and file with the applicable regulatory authorities this Schedule 13G or Schedule 13D and any future amendments thereto reporting each of the undersigned's ownership of securities of the issuer named herein, and hereby affirm that such Schedule 13G or Schedule 13D is being filed at the sole discretion of the filing party.
perturbation.explanation: The original text refers to filing the schedules in accordance with Rule 13d-1(k), whereas the modified text indicates filing is at the discretion of the filing party. This contradicts the mandatory nature of filing requirements.
perturbation.law_explanation: Rule 13d-1(k) mandates that filings be made pursuant to this rule. The modified text suggests that filings are discretionary, directly contradicting the legal requirement.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: 17 CFR § 240.13d-1 - Filing of Schedules 13D and 13G. | Electronic Code of Federal Regulations (e-CFR) | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute Please help us improve our site! × No thank you 17 CFR § 240.13d-1 - Filing of Schedules 13D and 13G. CFR Table of Popular Names prev | next § 240.13d-1 Filing of Schedules 13D and 13G. (a) Any person who, after acquiring directly or indirectly the beneficial ownership of any equity security of a class which is specified in paragraph (i)(1) of this section , is directly or indirectly the beneficial owner of more than five percent of the class shall, within five business days after the date of the acquisition, file with the Commission, a statement containing the information required by Schedule 13D (§ 240.13d-101) . (b) (1) A person who would otherwise be obligated under paragraph (a) of this section to file a statement on Schedule 13D (§ 240.13d-101) may, in lieu thereof, file with the Commission, a short-form statement on Schedule 13G (§ 240.13d-102), Provided, That: (i) Such person has acquired such securities in the ordinary course of the person's business and not with the purpose nor with the effect of changing or influencing the control of the issuer , nor in connection with or as a participant in any transaction having such purpose or effect, including any transaction subject to § 240.13d-3(b) and (ii) Such person is: (A) A broker or dealer registered under section 15 of the Act ( 15 U.S.C. 78o ); (B) A bank as defined in section 3(a)(6) of the Act ( 15 U.S.C. 78c ); (C) An insurance company as defined in section 3(a)(19) of the Act ( 15 U.S.C. 78c ); (D) An investment company registered under section 8 of the Investment Company Act of 1940 ( 15 U.S.C. 80a-8 ); (E) Any person registered as an investment adviser under Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 ( 15 U.S.C. 80b-3 ) or under the laws of any state; (F) An employee benefit plan as defined in Section 3(3) of the Employee Retirement Income Security A
perturbation.scraped_snippet_2: SEC.gov | Amendments to Beneficial Ownership Reporting Requirements Skip to search field Skip to main content Official websites use .gov A .gov website belongs to an official government organization in the United States. Secure .gov websites use HTTPS A lock ( Lock A locked padlock ) or https:// means you’ve safely connected to the .gov website. Share sensitive information only on official, secure websites. More in this Section Final Rule Copy Link Copied! Amendments to Beneficial Ownership Reporting Requirements Overview The Securities and Exchange Commission is today adopting amendments to its rules relating to the reporting of beneficial ownership in publicly held companies. These amendments make the short- form Schedule 13G available, in lieu of Schedule 13D, to all investors beneficially owning less than 20 percent of the outstanding class that have not acquired and do not hold the securities for the purpose of or with the effect of changing or influencing the control of the issuer of the securities. The purposes of the amendments are to improve the effectiveness of the beneficial ownership reporting scheme and to reduce the reporting obligations of passive investors. Prior Actions Proposed Rule (34-37403) Title Amendments to Beneficial Ownership Reporting Requirements Release Number 34-37403 34-39538 SEC Issue Date July 5, 1996 Federal Register Publish Date July 11, 1996 Document Citation 61 FR 36521 RIN 3235-AG81 Resources Proposed Rule: SEC Issued Version ( txt 121.93 KB) Proposed Rule: Federal Register Version Last Reviewed or Updated: April 7, 2023 Resources Final Rule: SEC Issued Version ( txt 100.9 KB) Final Rule: Federal Register Version is available Details File Number S7-16-96 Rule Type Final Release Number 34-39538 34-37403 SEC Issue Date Jan. 12, 1998 Effective Date Feb. 17, 1998. perturbation.justification: The original contract text explicitly states that filings will be done in accordance with Rule 13d-1(k), implying mandatory compliance. The changed text, however, indicates that filing is at the sole discretion of the filing party. This creates a strong contradiction because 17 CFR § 240.13d-1, as shown in Scraped Law Snippet 1, states that any person acquiring beneficial ownership of more than five percent of a class of equity security 'shall' file with the Commission. The use of 'shall' denotes a mandatory requirement, which is directly undermined by the modified text's discretionary clause. Snippet 2 reinforces this by discussing amendments to beneficial ownership reporting *requirements*, confirming that the filings are not optional. The perturbation explanation and law explanation accurately describe this contradiction.

perturbation.original_text: The undersigned acknowledge that each shall be responsible for the timely filing of such amendments, and for the completeness and accuracy of the information concerning her or it contained therein, but shall not be responsible for the completeness and accuracy of the information concerning the other, except to the extent that she or it knows or has reason to believe that such information is inaccurate.
perturbation.changed_text: The undersigned acknowledge that each shall only be responsible for the filing of such amendments if they deem it necessary, and they bear no responsibility for the completeness or accuracy of any information contained within the filing.
perturbation.explanation: The original text establishes responsibility for timely filing and accuracy. The modified version removes this responsibility, stating that filing is contingent on the filer's discretion and absolving them of accuracy concerns. This conflicts with SEC regulations mandating accurate and timely filings.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 13(d) of the Securities Exchange Act requires accurate and timely disclosure. By stating that filers have no responsibility for completeness or accuracy and the action is only performed as they 'deem it necessary', the modified text creates a contradiction of this requirement.

Periodical and other reports (a) Reports by issuer of security; contents Every issuer of a security registered pursuant to section 78l of this title shall file with the Commission, in accordance with such rules and regulations as the Commission may prescribe as necessary or appropriate for the proper protection of investors and to insure fair dealing in the security- (1) such information and documents (and su
perturbation.justification: The modified text removes responsibility for accurate and timely filing, which contradicts Section 13(a) of the Securities Exchange Act (15 USC 78m) as indicated in Scraped Law Snippet 1, which mandates issuers of registered securities to file information and documents with the Commission. The changed text, by stating that filing is at the discretion of the filer and absolving them of accuracy concerns, directly undermines the legal requirement for 'proper protection of investors and to insure fair dealing in the security.' The original text established this responsibility. The modification's explicit removal of this duty creates a substantial conflict, warranting a high contradiction score.
